awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Social Input to Scarce Resource Distribution
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Jason Yaeger and Mr. Sebastian Salgado-Flores, of The University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA), will examine the impact of social practices and ritual behavior on Postclassic Maya harvesting and management of firewood.  Because wood was the primary fuel for cooking food in pre-historic Mesoamerican societies, firewood harvesting put significant strain on the forests around ancient settlements.  The absence of beasts of burden limited harvesting to relatively short distances, and the preferred fuelwood trees grow slowly and were likely unable to meet the needs of a growing population. Thus, this research studies the wood charcoal from Postclassic Maya sites to determine whether their access to higher quality firewood declined over time, or whether the sites' inhabitants were able to overcome the challenges mentioned above and sustainably harvest preferred woods. The research will compare the taxa of firewood used in high-status residences, low-status residences, and public feasting events, in order to understand whether the strategies employed by elites to improve or maintain their social position included greater consumption of higher-quality wood fuels.  This project will involve collaboration with archaeologists at several universities in the United States and Mexico, the Comision Nacional de areas Naturales Protegidas in Mexico, and the Kleberg Advanced Microscopy Center at the University of Texas at San Antonio. This research will also refine archaeometric methods for estimating the diameter of a tree or branch from a charcoal fragment and will contribute to the training of a minority doctoral student in archaeobotanical methods and the use of a scanning election microscope.

Over the last several decades, research in anthracology (the study of charcoal recovered from archaeological sites) has become increasingly relevant to understanding of human-environment dynamics and how societies succeed or fail to achieve long-term resource security. The field's understanding of human fuelwood collection is currently based on a model guided by the "Principle of Least Effort," which expects wood gatherers to optimize the amount of energy gained in each harvest. Since the difference in heat release between higher and lower quality fuelwoods is marginal compared to the heavy labor cost of harvesting and transporting wood, this model assumes that ancient harvesters prioritized convenience and were relatively indiscriminating about which species they harvested. While this model appears to adequately explain species distribution of charcoal assemblages in some archaeological cases, it does not fully explain assemblages that are dominated by a few types of wood or differences in the species composition of assemblages deposited contemporaneously at the same archaeological site.  It also assumes that politics and social organization played little role in the way that cultures manage and consume fuelwood. Thus, this research will test the Principle of Least Effort model alongside an alternative model of firewood procurement grounded in Political Ecology and the social dynamics in Postclassic Maya communities.  This latter model hypothesizes that social elites in those communities found ways to preserve their access to preferred wood types. This model predicts that the charcoal assemblages produced by elite activity (particularly those produced by public events like feasting) will be more likely to contain preferred species than assemblages produced by non-elite households.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This goal of this project was to study the resource procurement strategies of fuelwood gatherers from Middle Postclassic to Protohistoric Maya (c.1150-1650 CE) sites in the Natural Protected Area of Metzabok in Chiapas, Mexico. It sought to understand what species of wood they collected, whether this makeup of species changed over time, and how the diversity of wood species collected corresponded to the diversity of species present in the local environment. NSF funding was used to accomplish several major research activities related to these goals: tree species surveys, archaeobotanical analysis, and radiocarbon dating of the archaeobotanical dataset. A team of indigenous Lacandon Maya forestry scientists and park rangers from the community of Metzabok completed a systematic tree survey of ten 50x20m plots distributed across areas of secondary forests, primary forests, and seasonal wetlands. The co-PI used scanning electron microscopy to photograph and analyze a robust archaeological charcoal assemblage and compared his results to those of the modern tree surveys.

The tree species surveys found significantly different tree communities growing across the three zones that were sampled (primary forest, secondary forest, and seasonal wetland). The charcoal assemblage analyzed by the co-PI most closely resembles the community of trees that grows in primary forests at the site today, though it also includes a significant amount of the predominant tree species found in the seasonal wetlands as well as non-local, imported pine. This suggests that the Postclassic Maya inhabitants of the Mensabak sites acquired preferred fuelwood from seasonal wetlands and primary forests, and via trade or tribute from other Maya communities living at higher elevations. None of the species that currently predominate in fallow fields/secondary forests were encountered in the archaeological charcoal assemblage. 

This project's findings introduce a crucial data point into the ongoing investigation of how people in the past obtained and managed scarce resources like firewood. Ancient people's use of firewood is rarely studied, particularly in the Americas. The dominant assumption in the field of archaeological charcoal studies, based mostly on observations of modern hunter-gatherers, is that people in the past were relatively indifferent to the species of firewood they collected and preferred to gather fuels in the form of twigs and fallen branches based on what was conveniently available in the local environment. Recently, more nuanced models have suggested that agricultural societies tend to gather fuelwood primarily from fallow agricultural fields. This project, which examined a charcoal assemblage produced by a sedentary Postclassic Maya community with an economy most likely based on fallow field agriculture, showed that the fuel-gatherers in that community had a strong affinity for denser high-heat-value fuel from species that grew in the seasonal wetlands and primary forests around them. They were also tied into a long-range economic network that supplied them with kindling in the form of pine wood that was not locally available. These results demonstrate the need for nuanced analysis of archaeological charcoal datasets that consider the cultural contexts in which they are deposited. This project makes a direct contribution to other disciplines which are engaged in reconstructing and understanding past environments. Its findings suggest that the diversity of charcoals recovered from human contexts are not necessarily representative of the diversity of wood types present in nearby forest communities. Rather, they reflect intentional selection by people seeking to obtain both the quantity and kind of fuelwood they need to satisfy culturally mediated wants and needs. 

The results of this project suggest that the Postclassic Maya community that lived around the Metzabok lakes preserved access to fuelwood from primary forests over a period of at least 500 years. This contradicts the prevailing narrative that ancestral Maya populations mismanaged local resources to the point of societal collapse; it shows instead that some communities successfully adapted management strategies tuned to local conditions. It shows that the knowledge and practices of indigenous peoples, often neglected in the design of conservation programs, can be compatible with and invaluable to accomplishing the goal of preserving the endangered Maya rainforest.
